paragraphs.original: In cold places that margin gets trimmed off. There's a sharper line between outside and inside, and only projects that are officially sanctioned — by organizations, or parents, or wives, or at least by oneself — get proper indoor space.
paragraphs.translated: 在寒冷的地方，这个边界会被削减。室内外之间的界限更加分明，只有得到正式认可的项目——无论是由组织、父母、妻子或是至少是自己认可的——才能获得合适的室内空间。

paragraphs.original: That raises the activation energy for new ideas. You can't just tinker. You have to justify.Some of Silicon Valley's most famous companies began in garages: Hewlett-Packard in 1938, Apple in 1976, Google in 1998.
paragraphs.translated: 这提高了新想法的激活能。你不能只是修补。你必须给出理由。硅谷一些最著名的公司就是在车库里起家的：1938年的惠普、1976年的苹果、1998年的谷歌。

paragraphs.original: In Apple's case the garage story is a bit of an urban legend. Woz says all they did there was assemble some computers, and that he did all the actual design of the Apple I and Apple II in his apartment or his cube at HP.
paragraphs.translated: 在苹果公司的案例中，车库的故事有点像都市传说。沃兹说，他们在那里只是组装了一些电脑，而苹果I和苹果II的实际设计工作都是他在自己的公寓或在惠普的工位上完成的。

paragraphs.original: [1] This was apparently too marginal even for Apple's PR people.By conventional standards, Jobs and Wozniak were marginal people too. Obviously they were smart, but they can't have looked good on paper.
paragraphs.translated: 这显然就连苹果的公关人员也觉得太边缘了。按常规标准来看，乔布斯和沃兹尼亚克也是边缘人物。显然他们很聪明，但他们的条件在纸面上看起来并不出色。

paragraphs.original: They were at the time a pair of college dropouts with about three years of school between them, and hippies to boot. Their previous business experience consisted of making "blue boxes" to hack into the phone system, a business with the rare distinction of being both illegal and unprofitable.OutsidersNow a startup operating out of a garage in Silicon Valley would feel part of an exalted tradition, like the poet in his garret, or the painter who can't afford to heat his studio and thus has to wear a beret indoors.
paragraphs.translated: 当时，他们是一对辍学的大学生，总共只上了三年学，而且还是嬉皮士。他们之前的商业经验仅限于制作“蓝盒子”来破解电话系统，这是一项既非法又无利可图的生意。如今，在硅谷的车库里经营一家初创公司会被视为一种高尚的传统，就像阁楼里的诗人，或者因为付不起暖气费而在室内戴着贝雷帽的画家。

paragraphs.original: But in 1976 it didn't seem so cool. The world hadn't yet realized that starting a computer company was in the same category as being a writer or a painter. It hadn't been for long. Only in the preceding couple years had the dramatic fall in the cost of hardware allowed outsiders to compete.In 1976, everyone looked down on a company operating out of a garage, including the founders.
paragraphs.translated: 但1976年时，这并不显得那么酷。当时的世界还没有意识到，创办一家电脑公司可以与成为作家或画家相提并论。这种情况并没有持续多久。只有在过去的几年里，硬件成本的大幅下降才使得外行人能够参与竞争。1976年，人们，包括创始人自己，都对在车库里经营的公司持轻视态度。

paragraphs.original: One of the first things Jobs did when they got some money was to rent office space. He wanted Apple to seem like a real company.They already had something few real companies ever have: a fabulously well designed product.
paragraphs.translated: 乔布斯一拿到钱做的第一件事就是租用办公空间。他希望苹果看起来像一家真正的公司。他们已经拥有了一种很少有真正公司能够拥有的东西：一款设计极其出色的产品。

paragraphs.original: You'd think they'd have had more confidence. But I've talked to a lot of startup founders, and it's always this way. They've built something that's going to change the world, and they're worried about some nit like not having proper business cards.That's the paradox I want to explore: great new things often come from the margins, and yet the people who discover them are looked down on by everyone, including themselves.It's an old idea that new things come from the margins.
paragraphs.translated: 你可能会认为他们应该更有信心。但我与许多初创公司的创始人交谈过，情况总是这样。他们创造了一些将要改变世界的东西，却在担心一些微不足道的问题，比如没有正规的名片。这就是我想探讨的悖论：伟大的新事物往往来自边缘，然而发现这些事物的人却受到包括他们自己在内所有人的轻视。新的事物来自边缘，这并不是一个新想法。

paragraphs.original: I want to examine its internal structure. Why do great ideas come from the margins? What kind of ideas? And is there anything we can do to encourage the process?InsidersOne reason so many good ideas come from the margin is simply that there's so much of it.
paragraphs.translated: 我想考察其内部结构。为什么伟大的想法来自边缘？是什么样的想法？我们能做些什么来促进这一过程？内部人士一个原因在于，之所以有这么多好想法来自边缘，仅仅是因为边缘的范围如此之广。

paragraphs.original: There have to be more outsiders than insiders, if insider means anything. If the number of outsiders is huge it will always seem as if a lot of ideas come from them, even if few do per capita. But I think there's more going on than this.
paragraphs.translated: 如果“内部人士”这个词有意义的话，那么外部人士的数量就必须多于内部人士。如果外部人士的数量庞大，即使他们中每个人提出的创意很少，也会给人一种有很多创意来自他们的错觉。但我认为，这背后还有更多的原因。

paragraphs.original: There are real disadvantages to being an insider, and in some kinds of work they can outweigh the advantages.Imagine, for example, what would happen if the government decided to commission someone to write an official Great American Novel.
paragraphs.translated: 成为内部人士确实存在真实的弊端，在某些类型的工作中，这些弊端可能会超过优势。例如，想象一下，如果政府决定委托某人撰写一部官方的“伟大的美国小说”，会发生什么。

paragraphs.original: First there'd be a huge ideological squabble over who to choose. Most of the best writers would be excluded for having offended one side or the other. Of the remainder, the smart ones would refuse such a job, leaving only a few with the wrong sort of ambition.
paragraphs.translated: 首先，会有一场巨大的意识形态争论，关于选择谁。大多数优秀的作家都会因为冒犯了某一方或另一方而被排除在外。在剩下的作家中，聪明的人会拒绝这样的工作，最终只剩下一些有错误野心的人。

paragraphs.original: The committee would choose one at the height of his career — that is, someone whose best work was behind him — and hand over the project with copious free advice about how the book should show in positive terms the strength and diversity of the American people, etc, etc.The unfortunate writer would then sit down to work with a huge weight of expectation on his shoulders.
paragraphs.translated: 委员会会在某个作家事业的巅峰时期挑选他——也就是说，选择一个最好的作品已经成为过去式的人——然后将项目交给他，并附带大量关于如何以正面的方式展示美国人民的力量和多样性的免费建议，等等。这位不幸的作家随后会带着巨大的期望压力坐下来开始工作。

paragraphs.original: Not wanting to blow such a public commission, he'd play it safe. This book had better command respect, and the way to ensure that would be to make it a tragedy. Audiences have to be enticed to laugh, but if you kill people they feel obliged to take you seriously.
paragraphs.translated: 他不想在这样一个公开的委托上出错，所以他会采取稳妥的做法。这本书必须赢得尊重，而确保这一点的方法就是把它写成悲剧。观众需要被引诱着笑，但如果你让人物死去，他们就会觉得有义务认真对待你。

paragraphs.original: As everyone knows, America plus tragedy equals the Civil War, so that's what it would have to be about. When finally completed twelve years later, the book would be a 900-page pastiche of existing popular novels — roughly Gone with the Wind plus Roots.
paragraphs.translated: 众所周知，美国加上悲剧就等于南北战争，所以这本书的内容也就必然是关于这一点。在历时十二年终于完成后，这本书会是一部900页的流行小说拼凑之作——大致相当于《飘》加上《根》。

paragraphs.original: But its bulk and celebrity would make it a bestseller for a few months, until blown out of the water by a talk-show host's autobiography. The book would be made into a movie and thereupon forgotten, except by the more waspish sort of reviewers, among whom it would be a byword for bogusness like Milli Vanilli or Battlefield Earth.Maybe I got a little carried away with this example.
paragraphs.translated: 但它的庞大和名气使它在几个月内成为畅销书，直到被一位脱口秀主持人的自传所超越。这本书后来被改编成电影，然后就被遗忘了，除了那些更为刻薄的评论家，他们将其视为虚假的代名词，就像米莉·范伊利或《 Battlefield Earth 》一样。也许我对这个例子有点夸大其词了。

paragraphs.original: And yet is this not at each point the way such a project would play out? The government knows better than to get into the novel business, but in other fields where they have a natural monopoly, like nuclear waste dumps, aircraft carriers, and regime change, you'd find plenty of projects isomorphic to this one — and indeed, plenty that were less successful.This little thought experiment suggests a few of the disadvantages of insider projects: the selection of the wrong kind of people, the excessive scope, the inability to take risks, the need to seem serious, the weight of expectations, the power of vested interests, the undiscerning audience, and perhaps most dangerous, the tendency of such work to become a duty rather than a pleasure.TestsA world with outsiders and insiders implies some kind of test for distinguishing between them.
paragraphs.translated: 然而，在每一个环节不都是如此吗？政府深知不应涉足小说创作，但在他们自然垄断的其他领域，如核废料处理场、航空母舰和政权更迭，你会发现许多与此类似的项目——事实上，还有许多不那么成功的项目。这个小小的思维实验揭示了内部项目的一些弊端：选错了人，范围过大，无法承担风险，需要显得严肃，期望的重压，既得利益的力量，不明就里的观众，也许最危险的是，这样的工作往往会变成一种责任而非乐趣。测试一个有内外之分的世界意味着需要某种测试来区分他们。

paragraphs.original: And the trouble with most tests for selecting elites is that there are two ways to pass them: to be good at what they try to measure, and to be good at hacking the test itself.So the first question to ask about a field is how honest its tests are, because this tells you what it means to be an outsider.
paragraphs.translated: 而大多数选拔精英的测试的问题在于，有两条途径可以过关：一是擅长它们试图衡量的能力，二是擅长破解测试本身。因此，对于一个领域，首先应该问的是其测试的诚实度如何，因为这告诉了你作为一个局外人意味着什么。

paragraphs.original: This tells you how much to trust your instincts when you disagree with authorities, whether it's worth going through the usual channels to become one yourself, and perhaps whether you want to work in this field at all.Tests are least hackable when there are consistent standards for quality, and the people running the test really care about its integrity.
paragraphs.translated: 这告诉你在与权威意见相左时应该多大程度上相信自己的直觉，是否值得通过常规渠道成为权威，也许还包括你是否真的想在这个领域工作。当有统一的质量标准，且负责测试的人真正关心其完整性时，测试是最难被操纵的。

paragraphs.original: Admissions to PhD programs in the hard sciences are fairly honest, for example. The professors will get whoever they admit as their own grad students, so they try hard to choose well, and they have a fair amount of data to go on.
paragraphs.translated: 理科博士项目的招生相对较为公正。教授们会将录取的学生作为自己的研究生，因此他们会努力做出好的选择，并且他们有相当多的数据可以参考。

paragraphs.original: Whereas undergraduate admissions seem to be much more hackable.One way to tell whether a field has consistent standards is the overlap between the leading practitioners and the people who teach the subject in universities.
paragraphs.translated: 而本科录取则似乎更容易操作。判断一个领域是否有统一标准的一个方法是，看该领域的顶尖从业者与在大学教授该课程的人之间的重叠程度。

paragraphs.original: At one end of the scale you have fields like math and physics, where nearly all the teachers are among the best practitioners. In the middle are medicine, law, history, architecture, and computer science, where many are.
paragraphs.translated: 在光谱的一端，有数学和物理这样的领域，几乎所有的教师都是顶尖的实践者。在中间的是医学、法律、历史、建筑和计算机科学，其中许多人是如此。

paragraphs.original: At the bottom are business, literature, and the visual arts, where there's almost no overlap between the teachers and the leading practitioners. It's this end that gives rise to phrases like "those who can't do, teach."Incidentally, this scale might be helpful in deciding what to study in college.
paragraphs.translated: 在底层是商业、文学和视觉艺术，这些领域中教师和顶尖从业者之间几乎没有交集。正是这种现象导致了“那些做不好的人去教书”这样的说法。顺便说一句，这个标准可能有助于决定大学里应该学习什么。

paragraphs.original: When I was in college the rule seemed to be that you should study whatever you were most interested in. But in retrospect you're probably better off studying something moderately interesting with someone who's good at it than something very interesting with someone who isn't.
paragraphs.translated: 我上大学时，似乎有一条规则，那就是你应该学习自己最感兴趣的领域。但回想起来，你可能还不如选择一个自己还算感兴趣且有良师指导的领域，而不是一个非常感兴趣但没有良师的领域。

paragraphs.original: You often hear people say that you shouldn't major in business in college, but this is actually an instance of a more general rule: don't learn things from teachers who are bad at them.How much you should worry about being an outsider depends on the quality of the insiders.
paragraphs.translated: 你经常听到人们说，你不应该在大学主修商业，但这实际上是一个更普遍规则的一个例子：不要从不擅长这些领域的人那里学习。你应该担心成为局外人有多严重，这取决于局内人的质量。

paragraphs.original: If you're an amateur mathematician and think you've solved a famous open problem, better go back and check. When I was in grad school, a friend in the math department had the job of replying to people who sent in proofs of Fermat's last theorem and so on, and it did not seem as if he saw it as a valuable source of tips — more like manning a mental health hotline.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你是一名业余数学家，并且认为自己解决了某个著名的未解问题，最好回去再检查一下。当我在研究生院时，数学系的一位朋友负责回复那些寄来费马大定理证明之类的人，他似乎并不认为这是获取有价值线索的来源——更像是在接听心理热线。

paragraphs.original: Whereas if the stuff you're writing seems different from what English professors are interested in, that's not necessarily a problem.Anti-TestsWhere the method of selecting the elite is thoroughly corrupt, most of the good people will be outsiders.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你写作的内容与英语教授们的兴趣不同，这未必是个问题。在选拔精英的方法彻底腐败的情况下，大多数优秀的人才都会成为局外人。

paragraphs.original: In art, for example, the image of the poor, misunderstood genius is not just one possible image of a great artist: it's the standard image. I'm not saying it's correct, incidentally, but it is telling how well this image has stuck.
paragraphs.translated: 在艺术领域，例如，贫穷、被误解的天才形象不仅仅是一种伟大艺术家的可能形象：它是标准形象。我并不是说这种形象是正确的，但这种形象如此深入人心，确实引人深思。

paragraphs.original: You couldn't make a rap like that stick to math or medicine. [2]If it's corrupt enough, a test becomes an anti-test, filtering out the people it should select by making them to do things only the wrong people would do.
paragraphs.translated: 你无法把那样的说唱用在数学或医学上。[2]如果腐败到了一定程度，考试就变成了反考试，通过让本应被选拔的人去做只有不合适的人才会做的事情，从而将他们筛选出去。

paragraphs.original: Popularity in high school seems to be such a test. There are plenty of similar ones in the grownup world. For example, rising up through the hierarchy of the average big company demands an attention to politics few thoughtful people could spare.
paragraphs.translated: 高中时期的受欢迎程度似乎是一种考验。成人世界里也有许多类似的考验。例如，在普通大公司的层级结构中晋升，需要关注政治，而这一点是很少有有思想的人愿意花费精力的。

paragraphs.original: [3] Someone like Bill Gates can grow a company under him, but it's hard to imagine him having the patience to climb the corporate ladder at General Electric — or Microsoft, actually.It's kind of strange when you think about it, because lord-of-the-flies schools and bureaucratic companies are both the default.
paragraphs.translated: 像比尔·盖茨这样的人可以在自己手下发展壮大一家公司，但很难想象他会有耐心在通用电气——或者实际上是在微软——的公司层级中逐步晋升。仔细想想，这其实挺奇怪的，因为强者生存的学校和官僚化的公司都是默认的状态。

paragraphs.original: There are probably a lot of people who go from one to the other and never realize the whole world doesn't work this way.I think that's one reason big companies are so often blindsided by startups. People at big companies don't realize the extent to which they live in an environment that is one large, ongoing test for the wrong qualities.If you're an outsider, your best chances for beating insiders are obviously in fields where corrupt tests select a lame elite.
paragraphs.translated: 可能有很多人从一个地方到另一个地方，却从未意识到整个世界并不是这样运作的。我认为这是大公司经常被初创企业打得措手不及的一个原因。大公司里的人没有意识到，他们生活在一个环境里，这个环境其实是一个大型的、持续进行的错误品质测试。如果你是一个局外人，你击败局内人的最佳机会显然在于那些腐败的测试选出的只是一个无能的精英群体的领域。

paragraphs.original: But there's a catch: if the tests are corrupt, your victory won't be recognized, at least in your lifetime. You may feel you don't need that, but history suggests it's dangerous to work in fields with corrupt tests.
paragraphs.translated: 但有一个问题：如果测试被操纵，你的胜利将不会被认可，至少在你的有生之年不会。你可能会觉得这无关紧要，但历史表明，在测试被操纵的领域工作是危险的。

paragraphs.original: You may beat the insiders, and yet not do as good work, on an absolute scale, as you would in a field that was more honest.Standards in art, for example, were almost as corrupt in the first half of the eighteenth century as they are today.
paragraphs.translated: 你可能会胜过那些内部人士，但在绝对意义上，你可能不会像在更诚实的领域那样做得出色。例如，18世纪前半叶的艺术标准几乎和今天一样腐败。

paragraphs.original: This was the era of those fluffy idealized portraits of countesses with their lapdogs. Chardin decided to skip all that and paint ordinary things as he saw them. He's now considered the best of that period — and yet not the equal of Leonardo or Bellini or Memling, who all had the additional encouragement of honest standards.It can be worth participating in a corrupt contest, however, if it's followed by another that isn't corrupt.
paragraphs.translated: 这正是那些画着贵妇人和她们宠物狗的柔美理想化肖像的时代。夏尔丹决定跳过这一切，如实描绘普通的事物。他现在被认为是那个时期最优秀的画家——然而仍不及达·芬奇、贝利尼或梅姆林，后者都因诚实的标准而得到了额外的激励。然而，如果一个腐败的竞赛之后跟着一个不腐败的竞赛，参与前者还是值得的。

paragraphs.original: For example, it would be worth competing with a company that can spend more than you on marketing, as long as you can survive to the next round, when customers compare your actual products. Similarly, you shouldn't be discouraged by the comparatively corrupt test of college admissions, because it's followed immediately by less hackable tests.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，只要你能撑到下一轮，当客户比较你们的实际产品时，与一家在营销上投入超过你的公司竞争是值得的。同样，你不应该因为大学录取的相对腐败的测试而气馁，因为紧接着会有较难作弊的测试。

paragraphs.original: [4]RiskEven in a field with honest tests, there are still advantages to being an outsider. The most obvious is that outsiders have nothing to lose. They can do risky things, and if they fail, so what?
paragraphs.translated: 即使在一个进行诚实测试的领域，作为局外人也有其优势。最明显的一点是，局外人没有什么可失去的。他们可以做冒险的事情，如果失败了，又怎么样呢？

paragraphs.original: Few will even notice.The eminent, on the other hand, are weighed down by their eminence. Eminence is like a suit: it impresses the wrong people, and it constrains the wearer.Outsiders should realize the advantage they have here.
paragraphs.translated: 很少有人会注意到这一点。然而，杰出人物却因他们的杰出而感到负担。杰出就像一套西装：它会给错误的人留下印象，同时也会束缚穿着者。局外人应该意识到他们在这里的优势。

paragraphs.original: Being able to take risks is hugely valuable. Everyone values safety too much, both the obscure and the eminent. No one wants to look like a fool. But it's very useful to be able to. If most of your ideas aren't stupid, you're probably being too conservative.
paragraphs.translated: 能够承担风险是非常宝贵的。每个人都过于重视安全，无论是无名之辈还是名人。没有人愿意显得愚蠢。但能够显得愚蠢其实是很有用的。如果你的大部分想法都不是愚蠢的，那么你可能过于保守了。

paragraphs.original: You're not bracketing the problem.Lord Acton said we should judge talent at its best and character at its worst. For example, if you write one great book and ten bad ones, you still count as a great writer — or at least, a better writer than someone who wrote eleven that were merely good.
paragraphs.translated: 你没有正确地界定问题。阿克顿勋爵说过，我们应该在一个人表现最好时评价其才能，在其表现最差时评价其品行。例如，如果你写了一本伟大的书和十本糟糕的书，你仍然算是一位伟大的作家——或者至少，比写了十一本仅仅不错的书的作家要好。

paragraphs.original: Whereas if you're a quiet, law-abiding citizen most of the time but occasionally cut someone up and bury them in your backyard, you're a bad guy.Almost everyone makes the mistake of treating ideas as if they were indications of character rather than talent — as if having a stupid idea made you stupid.
paragraphs.translated: 而如果你平时是个安静守法的公民，但偶尔会杀人碎尸并将尸体埋在自家后院，那你就是个坏人。几乎每个人都犯了一个错误，那就是把想法当作性格的标志而非才能的体现——仿佛有了一个愚蠢的想法就使你变得愚蠢。

paragraphs.original: There's a huge weight of tradition advising us to play it safe. "Even a fool is thought wise if he keeps silent," says the Old Testament (Proverbs 17:28).Well, that may be fine advice for a bunch of goatherds in Bronze Age Palestine.
paragraphs.translated: 有悠久的传统告诫我们要谨慎行事。“即使愚人，静默时也显得有智慧”，《旧约》（箴言 17:28）如是说。好吧，这也许是给青铜时代巴勒斯坦的一群牧羊人的好建议。

paragraphs.original: There conservatism would be the order of the day. But times have changed. It might still be reasonable to stick with the Old Testament in political questions, but materially the world now has a lot more state.
paragraphs.translated: 那时，保守主义是日常的准则。但时移世易。在政治问题上，坚持旧约或许仍有其合理性，但在物质方面，世界现在有了更多的国家干预。

paragraphs.original: Tradition is less of a guide, not just because things change faster, but because the space of possibilities is so large. The more complicated the world gets, the more valuable it is to be willing to look like a fool.DelegationAnd yet the more successful people become, the more heat they get if they screw up — or even seem to screw up.
paragraphs.translated: 传统作为指导的作用减弱了，不仅因为事物变化得更快，还因为可能性的空间如此之大。世界越复杂，愿意冒险看起来像傻瓜就越有价值。然而，人们越成功，如果他们出错——或者仅仅是看似出错——受到的批评就越多。

paragraphs.original: In this respect, as in many others, the eminent are prisoners of their own success. So the best way to understand the advantages of being an outsider may be to look at the disadvantages of being an insider.If you ask eminent people what's wrong with their lives, the first thing they'll complain about is the lack of time.
paragraphs.translated: 在这方面，如同许多其他方面一样，杰出人士成为了自己成功的囚徒。因此，要理解局外人的优势，最好的方法可能是看看局内人的劣势。如果你问杰出人士他们生活中有什么问题，他们首先会抱怨的是时间的缺乏。

paragraphs.original: A friend of mine at Google is fairly high up in the company and went to work for them long before they went public. In other words, he's now rich enough not to have to work. I asked him if he could still endure the annoyances of having a job, now that he didn't have to.
paragraphs.translated: 我的一位在谷歌的朋友，职位相当高，早在公司上市前就加入了。换句话说，他已经富得不需要工作了。我问他，既然现在已经不需要工作了，还能不能忍受工作中的烦心事。

paragraphs.original: And he said that there weren't really any annoyances, except — and he got a wistful look when he said this — that he got so much email.The eminent feel like everyone wants to take a bite out of them.
paragraphs.translated: 他说没有什么让他烦恼的事情，只是——说到这点时，他露出了一丝向往的神情——他收到的电子邮件太多了。名人们总是觉得每个人都想从他们身上分一杯羹。

paragraphs.original: The problem is so widespread that people pretending to be eminent do it by pretending to be overstretched.The lives of the eminent become scheduled, and that's not good for thinking. One of the great advantages of being an outsider is long, uninterrupted blocks of time.
paragraphs.translated: 这个问题如此普遍，以至于那些假装有名望的人通过表现得自己很忙来假装有名望。名望之人的生活变得被安排得满满当当，这对思考是不利的。作为一个局外人的一大优势就是拥有大段不受打扰的时间。

paragraphs.original: That's what I remember about grad school: apparently endless supplies of time, which I spent worrying about, but not writing, my dissertation. Obscurity is like health food — unpleasant, perhaps, but good for you.
paragraphs.translated: 这就是我对研究生院的记忆：看似无穷无尽的时间，我却用来担心而不是撰写我的论文。默默无闻就像健康食品——也许不讨人喜欢，但对你有好处。

paragraphs.original: Whereas fame tends to be like the alcohol produced by fermentation. When it reaches a certain concentration, it kills off the yeast that produced it.The eminent generally respond to the shortage of time by turning into managers.
paragraphs.translated: 名声往往像发酵产生的酒精。当它达到一定浓度时，就会杀死产生它的酵母。杰出人士通常会通过转变为管理者来应对时间的短缺。

paragraphs.original: They don't have time to work. They're surrounded by junior people they're supposed to help or supervise. The obvious solution is to have the junior people do the work. Some good stuff happens this way, but there are problems it doesn't work so well for: the kind where it helps to have everything in one head.For example, it recently emerged that the famous glass artist Dale Chihuly hasn't actually blown glass for 27 years.
paragraphs.translated: 他们没有时间工作，因为他们周围都是他们需要帮助或监督的初级员工。显而易见的解决办法是让初级员工来做这些工作。这样做确实能带来一些好的结果，但也存在一些问题，特别是那些需要将所有事情都装在一个脑子里的工作。例如，最近有消息透露，著名的玻璃艺术家戴尔·奇胡利实际上已经有27年没有亲自吹制玻璃了。

paragraphs.original: He has assistants do the work for him. But one of the most valuable sources of ideas in the visual arts is the resistance of the medium. That's why oil paintings look so different from watercolors. In principle you could make any mark in any medium; in practice the medium steers you.
paragraphs.translated: 他让助手为他完成工作。但在视觉艺术中，材料的抵抗性是创意的最宝贵来源之一。这就是为什么油画看起来与水彩画如此不同。从理论上讲，你可以在任何媒介中创作任何痕迹；但在实践中，媒介会引导你。

paragraphs.original: And if you're no longer doing the work yourself, you stop learning from this.So if you want to beat those eminent enough to delegate, one way to do it is to take advantage of direct contact with the medium.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你不再亲自做这项工作，你就不再从中学到东西。因此，如果你想超越那些地位显赫到可以委托他人的人，一个方法就是利用直接接触媒介的优势。

paragraphs.original: In the arts it's obvious how: blow your own glass, edit your own films, stage your own plays. And in the process pay close attention to accidents and to new ideas you have on the fly. This technique can be generalized to any sort of work: if you're an outsider, don't be ruled by plans.
paragraphs.translated: 在艺术领域，这一点显而易见：自己吹制玻璃，自己剪辑电影，自己导演戏剧。在这个过程中，要密切关注意外情况和突发的新想法。这种技巧可以推广到任何类型的工作：如果你是局外人，不要被计划所束缚。

paragraphs.original: Planning is often just a weakness forced on those who delegate.Is there a general rule for finding problems best solved in one head? Well, you can manufacture them by taking any project usually done by multiple people and trying to do it all yourself.
paragraphs.translated: 计划往往只是被迫施加给那些委托他人做事的人的一种弱点。是否存在一个普遍规则来找到最适合一个人解决的问题？嗯，你可以通过采取任何通常由多人完成的项目，尝试独自完成全部工作来制造这样的问题。

paragraphs.original: Wozniak's work was a classic example: he did everything himself, hardware and software, and the result was miraculous. He claims not one bug was ever found in the Apple II, in either hardware or software.Another way to find good problems to solve in one head is to focus on the grooves in the chocolate bar — the places where tasks are divided when they're split between several people.
paragraphs.translated: 沃兹尼亚克的工作就是一个经典的例子：他独自完成了所有的工作，包括硬件和软件，结果令人惊叹。他声称在苹果II上从未发现过任何硬件或软件的错误。另一种找到一个人可以解决的好问题的方法是关注巧克力条上的凹槽——即任务在多人之间分配时的分界点。

paragraphs.original: If you want to beat delegation, focus on a vertical slice: for example, be both writer and editor, or both design buildings and construct them.One especially good groove to span is the one between tools and things made with them.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你想超越委派，专注于一个垂直领域：例如，同时担任作家和编辑，或者既设计建筑又建造它们。一个特别好的跨越领域是工具与用这些工具制作的东西之间的领域。

paragraphs.original: For example, programming languages and applications are usually written by different people, and this is responsible for a lot of the worst flaws in programming languages. I think every language should be designed simultaneously with a large application written in it, the way C was with Unix.Techniques for competing with delegation translate well into business, because delegation is endemic there.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，编程语言和应用程序通常由不同的人编写，这导致了许多编程语言中最糟糕的缺陷。我认为每种语言都应与一个用该语言编写的大规模应用程序同时设计，就像C语言与Unix那样。竞争委派的技术在商业中也适用，因为委派在商业中非常普遍。

paragraphs.original: Instead of avoiding it as a drawback of senility, many companies embrace it as a sign of maturity. In big companies software is often designed, implemented, and sold by three separate types of people.
paragraphs.translated: 与其将其视为衰老的缺点而避免，许多公司反而将其视为成熟的标志。在大公司中，软件通常由三类不同的人分别进行设计、实施和销售。

paragraphs.original: In startups one person may have to do all three. And though this feels stressful, it's one reason startups win. The needs of customers and the means of satisfying them are all in one head.FocusThe very skill of insiders can be a weakness.
paragraphs.translated: 在创业公司，一个人可能需要身兼三职。尽管这会让人感到压力山大，但这也是创业公司能够获胜的原因之一。客户的需求和满足这些需求的方法都在同一个人的脑海中。专注内部人员的技能有时也可能成为一种弱点。

paragraphs.original: Once someone is good at something, they tend to spend all their time doing that. This kind of focus is very valuable, actually. Much of the skill of experts is the ability to ignore false trails. But focus has drawbacks: you don't learn from other fields, and when a new approach arrives, you may be the last to notice.For outsiders this translates into two ways to win.
paragraphs.translated: 一旦某人在某方面擅长，他们往往会把所有的时间都花在这件事上。这种专注实际上是非常有价值的。专家的许多技能在于能够忽略错误的方向。但专注也有缺点：你不会从其他领域学到东西，当出现新的方法时，你可能是最后一个注意到的人。对于局外人来说，这转化为两种获胜的方式。

paragraphs.original: One is to work on a variety of things. Since you can't derive as much benefit (yet) from a narrow focus, you may as well cast a wider net and derive what benefit you can from similarities between fields.
paragraphs.translated: 一是要涉猎多种事物。既然你目前还无法从专注于某一狭窄领域中获得太多好处，不妨撒开一张更宽的网，从不同领域的相似之处中尽可能地获取益处。

paragraphs.original: Just as you can compete with delegation by working on larger vertical slices, you can compete with specialization by working on larger horizontal slices — by both writing and illustrating your book, for example.The second way to compete with focus is to see what focus overlooks.
paragraphs.translated: 正如你可以通过处理更大的垂直切片来与委派竞争一样，你也可以通过处理更大的水平切片来与专业化竞争——例如，自己既写书又为书配图。与专注竞争的第二种方法是看到专注所忽视的东西。

paragraphs.original: In particular, new things. So if you're not good at anything yet, consider working on something so new that no one else is either. It won't have any prestige yet, if no one is good at it, but you'll have it all to yourself.The potential of a new medium is usually underestimated, precisely because no one has yet explored its possibilities.
paragraphs.translated: 特别是新事物。所以，如果你还没有擅长任何东西，可以考虑去研究一些连别人也不擅长的新领域。如果没有人擅长，它就不会有声望，但你可以独占这一领域。新媒介的潜力通常会被低估，正是因为还没有人去探索它的可能性。

paragraphs.original: Before Durer tried making engravings, no one took them very seriously. Engraving was for making little devotional images — basically fifteenth century baseball cards of saints. Trying to make masterpieces in this medium must have seemed to Durer's contemporaries the way that, say, making masterpieces in comics might seem to the average person today.In the computer world we get not new mediums but new platforms: the minicomputer, the microprocessor, the web-based application.
paragraphs.translated: 在丢勒尝试制作版画之前，没有人真正重视这种艺术形式。版画主要用于制作小的宗教图像——基本上相当于15世纪的圣人卡片。试图在这种媒介上创作杰作，在丢勒的同代人看来，可能就像今天普通人认为在漫画中创作杰作一样。在计算机世界中，我们得到的不是新的媒介，而是新的平台：小型计算机、微处理器、基于网络的应用程序。

paragraphs.original: At first they're always dismissed as being unsuitable for real work. And yet someone always decides to try anyway, and it turns out you can do more than anyone expected. So in the future when you hear people say of a new platform: yeah, it's popular and cheap, but not ready yet for real work, jump on it.As well as being more comfortable working on established lines, insiders generally have a vested interest in perpetuating them.
paragraphs.translated: 一开始，它们总是被认为不适合真正的工作。然而，总有人决定尝试一下，结果却发现它们能做到的远超所有人的预期。因此，将来当你听到有人对一个新平台说：是的，它很流行，也很便宜，但还不适合真正的工作时，不妨尝试一下。除了更习惯在既有的体系中工作外，内部人士通常也有利益关系，希望维持现状。

paragraphs.original: The professor who made his reputation by discovering some new idea is not likely to be the one to discover its replacement. This is particularly true with companies, who have not only skill and pride anchoring them to the status quo, but money as well.
paragraphs.translated: 那位因发现某个新思想而声名鹊起的教授，可能不会是发现其替代者的那个人。这种情况在公司中尤为明显，因为公司不仅有技能和自豪感将它们锚定在现状上，还有资金的因素。

paragraphs.original: The Achilles heel of successful companies is their inability to cannibalize themselves. Many innovations consist of replacing something with a cheaper alternative, and companies just don't want to see a path whose immediate effect is to cut an existing source of revenue.So if you're an outsider you should actively seek out contrarian projects.
paragraphs.translated: 成功公司的阿喀琉斯之踵是他们无法自我颠覆。许多创新都是用更便宜的替代品来取代某些东西，而公司往往不愿意看到一条会立即削减现有收入来源的道路。因此，如果你是局外人，应该积极寻找那些与主流观点相悖的项目。

paragraphs.original: Instead of working on things the eminent have made prestigious, work on things that could steal that prestige.The really juicy new approaches are not the ones insiders reject as impossible, but those they ignore as undignified.
paragraphs.translated: 不要去研究那些名人使其变得显赫的事物，而要去研究那些可能夺取那份显赫的事物。真正有前景的新方法并不是那些被业内人士认为不可能的方法，而是那些被他们视为不体面而忽略的方法。

paragraphs.original: For example, after Wozniak designed the Apple II he offered it first to his employer, HP. They passed. One of the reasons was that, to save money, he'd designed the Apple II to use a TV as a monitor, and HP felt they couldn't produce anything so declasse.LessWozniak used a TV as a monitor for the simple reason that he couldn't afford a monitor.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，沃兹尼亚克设计了苹果II之后，首先将它提供给了他的雇主惠普。但他们拒绝了。其中一个原因是，为了节省成本，他设计的苹果II使用电视作为显示器，而惠普觉得他们不能生产这么低档的产品。沃兹尼亚克使用电视作为显示器的简单原因是，他买不起专门的显示器。

paragraphs.original: Outsiders are not merely free but compelled to make things that are cheap and lightweight. And both are good bets for growth: cheap things spread faster, and lightweight things evolve faster.The eminent, on the other hand, are almost forced to work on a large scale.
paragraphs.translated: 外行人不仅有自由，而且被迫去制造便宜且轻便的东西。这两者都是增长的良好赌注：便宜的东西传播得更快，轻便的东西进化得更快。相比之下，杰出人士几乎被迫在大规模的项目上工作。

paragraphs.original: Instead of garden sheds they must design huge art museums. One reason they work on big things is that they can: like our hypothetical novelist, they're flattered by such opportunities. They also know that big projects will by their sheer bulk impress the audience.
paragraphs.translated: 他们需要设计的不是花园小屋，而是巨大的艺术博物馆。他们之所以从事大型项目，一方面是因为他们有能力这样做：就像我们假设中的小说家一样，他们被这样的机会所吸引。他们还知道，大型项目仅凭其庞大的体量就能给观众留下深刻印象。

paragraphs.original: A garden shed, however lovely, would be easy to ignore; a few might even snicker at it. You can't snicker at a giant museum, no matter how much you dislike it. And finally, there are all those people the eminent have working for them; they have to choose projects that can keep them all busy.Outsiders are free of all this.
paragraphs.translated: 一座花园小屋，无论多么可爱，都容易被忽视；有些人甚至可能会嘲笑它。你无法嘲笑一座巨大的博物馆，无论你有多么不喜欢它。最后，还有那些为显赫人物工作的人；他们必须选择能够让他们所有人都忙碌起来的项目。局外人则不受这一切的束缚。

paragraphs.original: They can work on small things, and there's something very pleasing about small things. Small things can be perfect; big ones always have something wrong with them. But there's a magic in small things that goes beyond such rational explanations.
paragraphs.translated: 他们可以从事小事情，而小事情本身有着某种非常令人愉悦的特质。小事情可以做到完美；而大事情总是有些地方不尽如人意。但在小事情中蕴含着一种魔力，这种魔力超越了理性的解释。

paragraphs.original: All kids know it. Small things have more personality.Plus making them is more fun. You can do what you want; you don't have to satisfy committees. And perhaps most important, small things can be done fast.
paragraphs.translated: 所有的孩子都知道这一点。小东西更有个性。而且制作它们更有趣。你可以随心所欲；不必迎合委员会。也许最重要的是，小东西可以快速完成。

paragraphs.original: The prospect of seeing the finished project hangs in the air like the smell of dinner cooking. If you work fast, maybe you could have it done tonight.Working on small things is also a good way to learn.
paragraphs.translated: 看到完成的项目的前景就像闻到正在烹饪的晚餐的香味一样。如果你动作快一点，也许今晚就能完成。做小项目也是学习的好方法。

paragraphs.original: The most important kinds of learning happen one project at a time. ("Next time, I won't...") The faster you cycle through projects, the faster you'll evolve.Plain materials have a charm like small scale.
paragraphs.translated: 最重要的学习是一次一个项目地进行。（“下次，我不会……”）你越快完成项目循环，你的进化就越快。朴素的材料有着小规模的魅力。

paragraphs.original: And in addition there's the challenge of making do with less. Every designer's ears perk up at the mention of that game, because it's a game you can't lose. Like the JV playing the varsity, if you even tie, you win.
paragraphs.translated: 此外，还有如何用更少的资源来应对挑战。每个设计师听到这个游戏都会竖起耳朵，因为这是一个你不会输的游戏。就像预备队对阵主力队，只要你能打平，就算赢了。

paragraphs.original: So paradoxically there are cases where fewer resources yield better results, because the designers' pleasure at their own ingenuity more than compensates. [5]So if you're an outsider, take advantage of your ability to make small and inexpensive things.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，矛盾的是，有些情况下资源越少反而能取得更好的结果，因为设计师对自己巧妙设计的满足感足以弥补资源的不足。[5]所以，如果你是一个局外人，利用你制作小型且成本低廉的项目的能力。

paragraphs.original: Cultivate the pleasure and simplicity of that kind of work; one day you'll miss it.ResponsibilityWhen you're old and eminent, what will you miss about being young and obscure? What people seem to miss most is the lack of responsibilities.Responsibility is an occupational disease of eminence.
paragraphs.translated: 培养这种工作的乐趣和简单；总有一天你会怀念它。责任当你年老有名时，你会怀念年轻无名时的什么？人们最怀念的似乎是缺乏责任。责任是名声显赫的职业病。

paragraphs.original: In principle you could avoid it, just as in principle you could avoid getting fat as you get old, but few do. I sometimes suspect that responsibility is a trap and that the most virtuous route would be to shirk it, but regardless it's certainly constraining.When you're an outsider you're constrained too, of course.
paragraphs.translated: 原则上你可以避免它，就像原则上你可以避免随着年龄增长而发胖，但很少有人能做到。我有时怀疑责任是个陷阱，最道德的路径可能是逃避它，但不管怎样，它确实是一种束缚。当你是个局外人时，你也会受到限制，当然。

paragraphs.original: You're short of money, for example. But that constrains you in different ways. How does responsibility constrain you? The worst thing is that it allows you not to focus on real work. Just as the most dangerous forms of procrastination are those that seem like work, the danger of responsibilities is not just that they can consume a whole day, but that they can do it without setting off the kind of alarms you'd set off if you spent a whole day sitting on a park bench.A lot of the pain of being an outsider is being aware of one's own procrastination.
paragraphs.translated: 你缺钱，例如。但这会在不同的方面限制你。责任又是如何限制你的呢？最糟糕的是，它让你无法专注于真正的工作。就像最危险的拖延形式是那些看起来像是在工作的情况一样，责任的危险性不仅在于它们可以占据一整天的时间，还在于它们可以做到这一点而不会触发你坐在公园长椅上一整天时会触发的那种警报。作为一个局外人，很多痛苦在于意识到自己的拖延。

paragraphs.original: But this is actually a good thing. You're at least close enough to work that the smell of it makes you hungry.As an outsider, you're just one step away from getting things done. A huge step, admittedly, and one that most people never seem to make, but only one step.
paragraphs.translated: 但其实这是一件好事。你至少离工作足够近，以至于它的气味都能让你感到饥饿。作为一个局外人，你离做成事情只差一步。诚然，这是巨大的一步，也是大多数人似乎从未迈出的一步，但确实只有一步之遥。

paragraphs.original: If you can summon up the energy to get started, you can work on projects with an intensity (in both senses) that few insiders can match. For insiders work turns into a duty, laden with responsibilities and expectations.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你能鼓足干劲开始，你可以以一种几乎无人能及的强度（从两个方面来说）投入到项目中。因为对于内部人士而言，工作变成了一种责任，充满了各种职责和期望。

paragraphs.original: It's never so pure as it was when they were young.Work like a dog being taken for a walk, instead of an ox being yoked to the plow. That's what they miss.AudienceA lot of outsiders make the mistake of doing the opposite; they admire the eminent so much that they copy even their flaws.
paragraphs.translated: 它从没有像他们年轻时那样纯净。工作像是被牵出去散步的狗，而不是被套上犁的牛。这正是他们所怀念的。很多外行人犯了相反的错误；他们如此仰慕那些显赫人物，以至于连他们的缺点也一并模仿。

paragraphs.original: Copying is a good way to learn, but copy the right things. When I was in college I imitated the pompous diction of famous professors. But this wasn't what made them eminent — it was more a flaw their eminence had allowed them to sink into.
paragraphs.translated: 模仿是学习的好方法，但要模仿正确的东西。我在大学时曾模仿著名教授们装腔作势的措辞。但这并不是他们杰出的原因——这更多是他们因杰出而陷入的一种缺陷。

paragraphs.original: Imitating it was like pretending to have gout in order to seem rich.Half the distinguishing qualities of the eminent are actually disadvantages. Imitating these is not only a waste of time, but will make you seem a fool to your models, who are often well aware of it.What are the genuine advantages of being an insider?
paragraphs.translated: 模仿它就像为了显得有钱而假装患有痛风。名人的许多显著特征实际上都是缺点。模仿这些不仅浪费时间，还会让你在那些往往对此心知肚明的模范人物面前显得愚蠢。成为局内人的真正优势是什么？

paragraphs.original: The greatest is an audience. It often seems to outsiders that the great advantage of insiders is money — that they have the resources to do what they want. But so do people who inherit money, and that doesn't seem to help, not as much as an audience.
paragraphs.translated: 最伟大的是观众。对于局外人来说，局内人的最大优势似乎是金钱——他们有资源去做自己想做的事情。但继承了财富的人也有这些资源，而这似乎并没有多大帮助，不如说，拥有观众更为重要。

paragraphs.original: It's good for morale to know people want to see what you're making; it draws work out of you.If I'm right that the defining advantage of insiders is an audience, then we live in exciting times, because just in the last ten years the Internet has made audiences a lot more liquid.
paragraphs.translated: 知道人们想看你制作的东西对士气有好处；这能激发你的工作热情。如果我所说的内部人士的优势在于拥有观众是对的话，那么我们正生活在一个令人兴奋的时代，因为在过去的十年里，互联网已经使观众变得更加流动。

paragraphs.original: Outsiders don't have to content themselves anymore with a proxy audience of a few smart friends. Now, thanks to the Internet, they can start to grow themselves actual audiences. This is great news for the marginal, who retain the advantages of outsiders while increasingly being able to siphon off what had till recently been the prerogative of the elite.Though the Web has been around for more than ten years, I think we're just beginning to see its democratizing effects.
paragraphs.translated: 局外人不再满足于只有少数聪明的朋友作为观众。现在，得益于互联网，他们可以开始培养自己的真正观众。这对边缘群体来说是个好消息，他们保留了局外人的优势，同时越来越能够获取过去只有精英才能享有的特权。虽然网络已经存在了十多年，但我认为我们才刚刚开始看到它的民主化效应。

paragraphs.original: Outsiders are still learning how to steal audiences. But more importantly, audiences are still learning how to be stolen — they're still just beginning to realize how much deeper bloggers can dig than journalists, how much more interesting a democratic news site can be than a front page controlled by editors, and how much funnier a bunch of kids with webcams can be than mass-produced sitcoms.The big media companies shouldn't worry that people will post their copyrighted material on YouTube.
paragraphs.translated: 局外人仍在学习如何吸引观众。但更重要的是，观众仍在学习如何被吸引——他们才刚刚开始意识到，博主能够挖掘的深度远超记者，民主化的新闻网站比由编辑控制的首页有趣得多，而一群拿着网络摄像头的孩子比量产的情景喜剧更搞笑。大型媒体公司不必担心人们会在YouTube上发布他们的版权内容。

paragraphs.original: They should worry that people will post their own stuff on YouTube, and audiences will watch that instead.HackingIf I had to condense the power of the marginal into one sentence it would be: just try hacking something together.
paragraphs.translated: 他们应该担心人们会在YouTube上发布自己的内容，而观众会观看这些内容。至于边缘力量，如果我要用一句话概括，那就是：试着拼凑一些东西出来。

paragraphs.original: That phrase draws in most threads I've mentioned here. Hacking something together means deciding what to do as you're doing it, not a subordinate executing the vision of his boss. It implies the result won't be pretty, because it will be made quickly out of inadequate materials.
paragraphs.translated: 这句话概括了我在这里提到的大部分内容。拼凑某事意味着在做的过程中决定要做什么，而不是下属执行老板的愿景。这暗示着结果不会太完美，因为它会用不充分的材料快速制作出来。

paragraphs.original: It may work, but it won't be the sort of thing the eminent would want to put their name on. Something hacked together means something that barely solves the problem, or maybe doesn't solve the problem at all, but another you discovered en route.
paragraphs.translated: 这可能行得通，但不会是那些知名人士愿意署名的东西。拼凑出来的东西意味着勉强解决了问题，或者根本没解决问题，而是你在途中发现的另一个问题。

paragraphs.original: But that's ok, because the main value of that initial version is not the thing itself, but what it leads to. Insiders who daren't walk through the mud in their nice clothes will never make it to the solid ground on the other side.The word "try" is an especially valuable component.
paragraphs.translated: 但没关系，因为那个初始版本的主要价值不在于其本身，而在于它所引导的结果。那些不敢穿着漂亮衣服涉泥前行的内部人士，永远无法到达另一边的坚实地面。“尝试”这个词尤其是一个有价值的组成部分。

paragraphs.original: I disagree here with Yoda, who said there is no try. There is try. It implies there's no punishment if you fail. You're driven by curiosity instead of duty. That means the wind of procrastination will be in your favor: instead of avoiding this work, this will be what you do as a way of avoiding other work.
paragraphs.translated: 我在这里不同意尤达的说法，他认为没有尝试这回事。尝试是存在的。这暗示着如果你失败了，不会受到惩罚。你是由好奇心而非责任驱动的。这意味着拖延的风将会对你有利：与其回避这项工作，这反而会成为你回避其他工作的手段。

paragraphs.original: And when you do it, you'll be in a better mood. The more the work depends on imagination, the more that matters, because most people have more ideas when they're happy.If I could go back and redo my twenties, that would be one thing I'd do more of: just try hacking things together.
paragraphs.translated: 当你这么做的时候，你的心情会更好。工作越依赖于想象力，这一点就越重要，因为大多数人开心时会有更多的想法。如果我能回到二十多岁重新来过，我会多做一件事：就是多尝试拼凑些东西。

paragraphs.original: Like many people that age, I spent a lot of time worrying about what I should do. I also spent some time trying to build stuff. I should have spent less time worrying and more time building. If you're not sure what to do, make something.Raymond Chandler's advice to thriller writers was "When in doubt, have a man come through a door with a gun in his hand." He followed that advice.
paragraphs.translated: 像那个年纪的许多人一样，我花了很多时间担心自己该做什么。我也花了一些时间尝试建造东西。我本应该少担心，多建造。如果你不确定该做什么，那就去创造一些东西。雷蒙德·钱德勒给惊悚小说作家的建议是：“如果感到迷茫，就让一个手里拿着枪的人从门里走进来。”他自己也遵循了这一建议。

paragraphs.original: Judging from his books, he was often in doubt. But though the result is occasionally cheesy, it's never boring. In life, as in books, action is underrated.Fortunately the number of things you can just hack together keeps increasing.
paragraphs.translated: 从他的书来看，他常常充满疑虑。但尽管结果有时显得有些俗套，却从不无聊。在生活中，就像在书中一样，行动总是被低估了。幸运的是，你可以随意拼凑的事情越来越多。

paragraphs.original: People fifty years ago would be astonished that one could just hack together a movie, for example. Now you can even hack together distribution. Just make stuff and put it online.InappropriateIf you really want to score big, the place to focus is the margin of the margin: the territories only recently captured from the insiders.
paragraphs.translated: 五十年前的人们会惊讶于现在可以如此简单地制作一部电影。现在，你甚至可以轻松地处理发行。只需制作内容并将其放到网上。如果你真的想大获成功，应该关注的是边缘的边缘：那些最近才从内部人士手中夺取的领域。

paragraphs.original: That's where you'll find the juiciest projects still undone, either because they seemed too risky, or simply because there were too few insiders to explore everything.This is why I spend most of my time writing essays lately.
paragraphs.translated: 在那里，你会发现那些尚未完成的最有潜力的项目，要么是因为它们看起来风险太大，要么是因为内部人士太少而无法探索一切。这就是我最近大部分时间都在写文章的原因。

paragraphs.original: The writing of essays used to be limited to those who could get them published. In principle you could have written them and just shown them to your friends; in practice that didn't work. [6] An essayist needs the resistance of an audience, just as an engraver needs the resistance of the plate.Up till a few years ago, writing essays was the ultimate insider's game.
paragraphs.translated: 写散文曾经仅限于那些能够将其发表的人。原则上，你可以写出来并只给朋友们看看；但实际上这行不通。[6] 散文作者需要读者的反馈，就像雕刻家需要铜板的阻力一样。直到几年前，写散文还是个圈内人的游戏。

paragraphs.original: Domain experts were allowed to publish essays about their field, but the pool allowed to write on general topics was about eight people who went to the right parties in New York. Now the reconquista has overrun this territory, and, not surprisingly, found it sparsely cultivated.
paragraphs.translated: 领域专家被允许发表关于其专业的文章，但撰写一般主题的文章的人数大约只有八人，这些人参加了纽约的正确聚会。现在，这场重新征服已经占领了这一领域，不出所料，发现这里开发得并不充分。

paragraphs.original: There are so many essays yet unwritten. They tend to be the naughtier ones; the insiders have pretty much exhausted the motherhood and apple pie topics.This leads to my final suggestion: a technique for determining when you're on the right track.
paragraphs.translated: 还有许多文章尚未撰写。这些往往是较为大胆的；内部人士已经差不多把那些人人皆知的话题写尽了。这引出了我的最后一条建议：一种判断你是否走在正确道路上的技巧。

paragraphs.original: You're on the right track when people complain that you're unqualified, or that you've done something inappropriate. If people are complaining, that means you're doing something rather than sitting around, which is the first step.
paragraphs.translated: 当人们抱怨你不合格，或者你做了什么不恰当的事情时，你已经在正确的道路上了。如果有人抱怨，这意味着你在行动，而不是无所事事，这是第一步。

paragraphs.original: And if they're driven to such empty forms of complaint, that means you've probably done something good.If you make something and people complain that it doesn't work, that's a problem. But if the worst thing they can hit you with is your own status as an outsider, that implies that in every other respect you've succeeded.
paragraphs.translated: 如果他们只能诉诸这种空洞的抱怨，那就意味着你可能做了件好事。如果你做出的东西人们抱怨说它不起作用，那确实是个问题。但若他们能用来攻击你的最糟糕的事情只是你作为一个局外人的身份，这表明在其他所有方面你已经成功了。

paragraphs.original: Pointing out that someone is unqualified is as desperate as resorting to racial slurs. It's just a legitimate sounding way of saying: we don't like your type around here.But the best thing of all is when people call what you're doing inappropriate.
paragraphs.translated: 指出某人不合格就像使用种族侮辱一样绝望。这只不过是一种听起来合理的方式来表达：我们不喜欢你这种人在这里。但最妙的是，当人们说你做的事情不合适时。

paragraphs.original: I've been hearing this word all my life and I only recently realized that it is, in fact, the sound of the homing beacon. "Inappropriate" is the null criticism. It's merely the adjective form of "I don't like it."So that, I think, should be the highest goal for the marginal.
paragraphs.translated: 我这一生经常听到这个词，直到最近我才意识到，它实际上是归航信标的声响。“不恰当”是最空洞的批评。它只不过是“我不喜欢它”的形容词形式。所以，我认为，这应该是边缘群体的最高目标。

paragraphs.original: Be inappropriate. When you hear people saying that, you're golden. And they, incidentally, are busted.Notes[1] The facts about Apple's early history are from an interview with Steve Wozniak in Jessica Livingston's Founders at Work.[2] As usual the popular image is several decades behind reality.
paragraphs.translated: 当别人说你“不合适”时，你就有机会了。而他们，顺便说一句，就输了。注释[1] 关于苹果早期历史的事实来自史蒂夫·沃兹尼亚克在杰西卡·利文斯顿的《创业维艰》一书中的访谈。[2] 通常，大众印象总是落后于现实几十年。

paragraphs.original: Now the misunderstood artist is not a chain-smoking drunk who pours his soul into big, messy canvases that philistines see and say "that's not art" because it isn't a picture of anything. The philistines have now been trained that anything hung on a wall is art.
paragraphs.translated: 如今，被误解的艺术家不再是那个烟不离手、酗酒成性的家伙，他将自己的灵魂倾注在那些大而凌乱的画布上，而外行人看到后会说“这不是艺术”，因为它什么都不像。现在，这些外行人已经被训练得认为，墙上挂的任何东西都是艺术。

paragraphs.original: Now the misunderstood artist is a coffee-drinking vegan cartoonist whose work they see and say "that's not art" because it looks like stuff they've seen in the Sunday paper.[3] In fact this would do fairly well as a definition of politics: what determines rank in the absence of objective tests.[4] In high school you're led to believe your whole future depends on where you go to college, but it turns out only to buy you a couple years.
paragraphs.translated: 现在，被误解的艺术家是一位喝咖啡的素食主义漫画家，人们看到他的作品时会说“这不算艺术”，因为它看起来像是他们在周日报纸上见过的东西。事实上，这可以很好地作为对政治的定义：在没有客观标准的情况下，如何决定地位。在高中时，你可能会以为你的整个未来取决于你上哪所大学，但事实证明，这只能为你赢得几年的时间。

paragraphs.original: By your mid-twenties the people worth impressing already judge you more by what you've done than where you went to school.[5] Managers are presumably wondering, how can I make this miracle happen? How can I make the people working for me do more with less?
paragraphs.translated: 到你二十五六岁的时候，那些值得你印象的人已经更多地根据你的实际表现而不是你上过什么学校来评判你。[5] 经理们可能在想，我如何才能创造这个奇迹？我如何才能让我的员工用更少的资源做更多的事情？

paragraphs.original: Unfortunately the constraint probably has to be self-imposed. If you're expected to do more with less, then you're being starved, not eating virtuously.[6] Without the prospect of publication, the closest most people come to writing essays is to write in a journal.
paragraphs.translated: 不幸的是，这种约束可能需要自我施加。如果你被期望用更少的资源做更多的事情，那么你是在被剥夺，而不是在进行有节制的饮食。[6] 没有发表的前景，大多数人最接近写作文的情况就是写日记。

paragraphs.original: I find I never get as deeply into subjects as I do in proper essays. As the name implies, you don't go back and rewrite journal entries over and over for two weeks.Thanks to Sam Altman, Trevor Blackwell, Paul Buchheit, Sarah Harlin, Jessica Livingston, Jackie McDonough, Robert Morris, Olin Shivers, and Chris Small for reading drafts of this, and to Chris Small and Chad Fowler for inviting me to speak.
paragraphs.translated: 我发现我从未像写正式论文那样深入探讨过主题。正如其名称所示，你不会花两周时间反复回去重写日记条目。感谢Sam Altman、Trevor Blackwell、Paul Buchheit、Sarah Harlin、Jessica Livingston、Jackie McDonough、Robert Morris、Olin Shivers和Chris Small阅读本文的草稿，也感谢Chris Small和Chad Fowler邀请我作演讲。
